<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 305, 220, 320]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 305, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
9709/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 304, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics 1 (M1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 327, 907, 344]]<|/det|>
October/November 2019  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 350, 907, 365]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 320, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 907, 571]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 907, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 600, 724, 615]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 615, 593, 630]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 630, 606, 645]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 658, 606, 673]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 674, 756, 689]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 689, 440, 704]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A crate of mass \(500\mathrm{kg}\) is being pulled along rough horizontal ground by a horizontal rope attached to a winch. The winch produces a constant pulling force of \(2500\mathrm{N}\) and the crate is moving at constant speed. Find the coefficient of friction between the crate and the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
A train of mass \(150000\mathrm{kg}\) ascends a straight slope inclined at \(\alpha^{\circ}\) to the horizontal with a constant driving force of \(16 000\mathrm{N}\). At a point \(A\) on the slope the speed of the train is \(45\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\). Point \(B\) on the slope is \(500\mathrm{m}\) beyond \(A\). At \(B\) the speed of the train is \(42\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\). There is a resistance force acting on the train and the train does \(4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~J}\) of work against this resistance force between \(A\) and \(B\). Find the value of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 920, 156]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 84, 678, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 272, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
Three coplanar forces of magnitudes \(50 \mathrm{N}, 60 \mathrm{N}\) and \(100 \mathrm{N}\) act at a point. The resultant of the forces has magnitude \(R \mathrm{N}\). The directions of these forces are shown in the diagram. Find the values of \(R\) and \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 306, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A car travels along a straight road with constant acceleration. It passes through points \(P\), \(Q\), \(R\) and \(S\). The times taken for the car to travel from \(P\) to \(Q\), \(Q\) to \(R\) and \(R\) to \(S\) are each equal to \(10 \mathrm{~s}\). The distance \(QR\) is \(1.5\) times the distance \(PQ\). At point \(Q\) the speed of the car is \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 137, 156, 155]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 136, 549, 155]]<|/det|>
Show that the acceleration of the car is \(0.8 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 818, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the distance \(QS\) and hence find the average speed of the car between \(Q\) and \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The cyclist later ascends a straight hill inclined at \(3^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. His power output and the resistance force are still both unchanged. Find his acceleration when he is travelling at \(4 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Particle \(P\) travels in a straight line from \(A\) to \(B\). The velocity of \(P\) at time \(t\) s after leaving \(A\) is denoted by \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 109, 584, 129]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = 0.04t^{3} + ct^{2} + kt.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 880, 153]]<|/det|>
\(P\) takes 5 s to travel from \(A\) to \(B\) and it reaches \(B\) with speed \(10 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). The distance \(AB\) is \(25 \mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 166, 154, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 165, 479, 184]]<|/det|>
Find the values of the constants \(c\) and \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 84, 640, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 299, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(A\) and \(B\) have masses \(m \mathrm{kg}\) and \(km \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, where \(k > 1\). The particles are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley and the particles hang vertically below it. Both particles are at a height of \(0.81 \mathrm{m}\) above horizontal ground (see diagram). The system is released from rest and particle \(B\) reaches the ground \(0.9 \mathrm{s}\) later. The particle \(A\) does not reach the pulley in its subsequent motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 393, 156, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 393, 920, 427]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\) and show that the tension in the string before \(B\) reaches the ground is equal to \(12m \mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 411, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 594, 92]]<|/det|>
At the instant when \(B\) reaches the ground, the string breaks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 106, 153, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Show that the speed of \(A\) when it reaches the ground is \(5.97 \text{ m s}^{-1}\), correct to 3 significant figures, and find the time taken, after the string breaks, for \(A\) to reach the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 660, 185, 677]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 657, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
Sketch a velocity-time graph for the motion of particle \(A\) from the instant when the system is released until \(A\) reaches the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 675, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 74, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
